heading: compaq seeks broadband edge
subheading: the computer maker ships machines with the gear needed to support high-speed internet access to the home. when it gets there.
author: wired news report
text: compaq began shipping home computers tuesday equipped with hardware to provide cheap, broadband network access in the home. the machines will also allow users to create personal networks using existing household phone lines.the computers contain a modem combining digital subscriber line with cable modem hardware to access the internet at speeds better than 1mbps. with the purchase of supplemental software, the company said that consumers will be able to easily build home networks out of a standard built-in phone network.the products include the 1200 series internet notebooks, which are powered by the 333 mhz amd k6 processor and start at us$1,499, and the presario 5600i, which starts at $1,468. both include a "phone-line network card" and a 17-inch monitor.later this month, the company will offer a "networked home in a box" option that includes the network software, two pcs, a monitor, and a printer. pricing for this option is expected to be under $2,500.but consumers may still run into roadblocks attempting to use the hardware to access the internet at broadband speeds.cable modem and xdsl access is still dependent on availability from service providers, and the ability to network computers through home phone lines is still largely dependent on the quality of phone wiring in the home.
